WKU rolls 45-7 in home finale, bowl eligible

Michael Grant, mgrant@courier-journal.com 6:04 p.m. EST November 22, 2014

Nov 22, 2014; Bowling Green, KY, USA; Western Kentucky Hilltoppers quarterback Brandon Doughty (12) looks to throw the ball against the UTSA Roadrunners at Houchens Industries-L.T. Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Joshua Lindsey-USA TODAY Sports(Photo: Joshua Lindsey / Joshua Lindsey-USA TODAY Sports)

CONNECT 3 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

BOWLING GREEN, Ky. - Western Kentucky University picked an ideal time to play its most complete football game of the season.

WKU crushed UTSA 45-7 in its home finale on Saturday to become bowl eligible for the fourth straight year. Brandon Doughty, one of 18 seniors, passed for 346 yards and five touchdowns.

The Hilltoppers (6-5, 3-4 Conference USA) didn't allow a score until the fourth quarter. They rolled up 466 total yards with no turnovers, didn't allow a sack and were called for only four penalties.

"It was a great effort by our guys today," WKU coach Jeff Brohm said. "I couldn't be prouder of their performance. They definitely continue to improve every week."

WKU has won three straight to give itself a chance at a postseason berth. This latest victory sets up a showdown at No.18 Marshall (11-0, 7-0) on Friday.

Marshall and defending national champion Florida State are the only unbeatens left in the FBS.

"We've been in a playoff mentality," Brohm said. "Our guys have responded to it. We look forward to the competition getting tougher. We play against an undefeated team with a lot of implications for them riding on this game. It's a great opportunity for us."

WKU grabbed a 14-0 first-quarter lead on UTSA. This was the Hilltoppers' usual pass-first formula. Last week, they altered the plan as tailback Leon Allen set a C-USA record with 345 rushing yards. On Saturday, Doughty threw TD passes of 54, 47, 67, 13 and 16 yards for a 35-0 third-quarter lead.

The most spectacular score was the 67-yarder to fellow senior Willie McNeal. It looked like the UTSA defender was going to knock it away. McNeal somehow caught the tipped pass and sprinted into the end zone to make the score 21-0.

"Nicholas (Norris) was picking on me on the sidelines saying I'm always getting the lucky catches because of the Hail Mary last week," said McNeal who had seven catches for 105 yards.

With all that offense, UTSA didn't stand much of a chance. The Roadrunners are down to their third string quarterback: Austin Robinson due to injuries. They haven't scored more than 20 points since late September. On Saturday, they finished with 234 total yards.

UTSA had more ejections (2) than TDs. Safety Michael Egwuagu was tossed for targeting on WKU tight end Mitchell Henry. Defensive tackle Brian Price was ejected after tossing a referee to the ground.

WKU entered this game allowing 39.8 points per game fourth most in the nation. Against UTSA, it almost pitched its first shutout since 2011 when it beat Florida Atlantic 20-0.

UTSA finally broke through on a 47-yard TD pass with 8:49 left. The Hilltoppers defense hadn't allowed a fourth-quarter score in their previous three home games.

"I didn't want them to get anything," senior cornerback Cam Thomas said of UTSA. "To see our defense progress throughout the season, I told those guys that I believe in them."

Now the Hilltoppers face the biggest challenge of the season: a trip to Marshall.

"I'm ready," Thomas said. "I'm excited. You look for games like that, especially to knock off an undefeated team. That's a championship game for us."

Contact Michael Grant at (502) 582-4069, and on Twitter @MichaelGrant_CJ
